author: Colleen Goko
title: Glencore tumbles to record low as investor confidence plunges | Companies
text:
Ivan Glasenberg. Picture: REUTERS Related articles Stocks, dollar subdued at start of heavy data week Glencore hires banks to sell stake in its agriculture unit Glencore's Zambian unit plans to lay off workers Glencore takes heat as losses pick up speed In this article Companies and organisations: Glencore Xstrata GLN View company tearsheet GLOBAL diversified miner Glencore experienced a blue Monday as investors sent the stock plunging by close to 30% in midday trade.
The struggling miner has seemingly failed to convince shareholders that it will be able to meet its net debt targets if commodity prices remain low or fall further.
Glencore has previously said it plans to reduce its net debt by a third to around $20bn by the end of 2016.
Just last week, the company’s management invested millions of pounds to take up shares in the group’s $2.5bn placing to bring down debt.
CEO Ivan Glasenberg put in £137.6m to maintain his stake in Glencore at 8.42%, while directors Daniel Mate invested £52.7m to keep his stake at 3.22% and Telis Mistakidis £51.8m for 3.17%.
This, however, was not enough to sway market opinion or sentiment.
Investec analyst Hunter Hillcoat in a research note said mining companies had "gorged" themselves on cheap debt in a race to grow production following the Chinese stimulus that occurred in the wake of the global financial crisis.
"The consequences are only now coming home to roost, as mines take a long time to build. We expect commodity markets to remain subdued for several years to come given that excess supply has coincided with a slowdown in demand.
"If major commodity prices remain at current levels, our analysis implies that, in the absence of substantial restructuring, nearly all the equity value of both Glencore and Anglo American could evaporate," said Mr Hillcoat.
Prices for several key commodities that Glencore produces have fallen to multiyear lows as a result of a combination of excess supply and slower Chinese economic growth.
Copper, the company's biggest earnings driver and a barometer for the health of the global economy, is down a fifth so far this year, having hit a six-year low last month.
At 12.38pm, Glencore was down 23.53% to R16.02.
In the last year, Glencore has lost 74% of its value.
The company is currently valued at about R306bn.
